Core Idea: Children actively construct knowledge through specific stages.
Example: Child learns by manipulating objects to understand physics.

Core Idea: Behavior evolves to solve survival problems.
Example: Stranger anxiety keeps infants close to caregivers for safety.

column8: A child fears the dentist because of past pain (conditioning).

View of Child: Unconscious conflicts and early experiences shape personality.
column7: Strict toilet training leads to fixation on control/orderliness.

column8: A child watches a sibling get punished and learns not to do that behavior.

Core Idea: Cultural context and social interaction drive development.
Example: Learning math concepts through interaction with a more skilled peer.

column8: "A parent's job loss (exosystem) increases stress at home (microsystem)."

Example: "Cannot show individual change; prone to cohort effects (generational differences)."

View of Child: Separates age effects from cohort effects.

Example: "No safe amount exists; leading preventable cause of ID."

column7: Reduces oxygen to fetus via placenta.

column8: Dangerous only if mother contracts it during early pregnancy.

View of Child: Object Permanence (knowing things exist when unseen).
Example: Infant searches for a hidden toy (approx. 8–12 months).

Key Figures: "Seeks comfort; easily soothed; returns to play."
"Ignores parent; looks away; does not seek comfort."

View of Child: "Obedient but anxious; poor communication skills; rebellious."

Core Idea: "Regular routines; positive mood; adapts easily to new situations."
"Irregular routines; negative mood; intense reactions; resists change."
"Low activity level; somewhat negative; withdraws from new situations initially."
View of Child: "Needs time to adjust; allow child to set own pace."

Core Idea: Gap between IQ and academic achievement (Reading/Math)
View of Child: "Difficulty reading (Dyslexia) or Math (Dyscalculia) despite normal intelligence."
